nodes.text: Rank-based intergenerational mobility in the United States has remained stable for birth cohorts 1971–1993 despite rising income inequality
Data: linked administrative tax records and SOI cross sections covering children born 1971–1993, population-based sample for 1980–1993 and SOI sample for 1971–1982

Measurement: decompose joint parent-child income distribution into copula (rank relationship) and marginal distributions; use rank-rank regressions, quintile transition matrices, and college attendance gradients
Assumption: rank-based measures (copula) capture relative mobility and can be interpreted separately from changes in marginal income distributions
Evidence from rank-rank regressions: rank-rank slopes for 1971–1982 cohorts are approximately 0.30 and show no trend; estimates robust to age and measurement choices

Evidence from college attendance gradients: gap in college attendance between lowest- and highest-income parents held roughly constant around 74.5 percent for 1984–1989 cohorts and modestly fell to 69.2 percent for 1993 cohort
Evidence from transition matrices: probability of a child from bottom parental quintile reaching the top quintile was 8.4 percent in 1971 and 9.0 percent in 1986, showing little change
Result: marginal income distributions widened substantially over time; Gini coefficients and top 1 percent shares increased for parents and children

Claim: Because marginal distributions widened while the copula remained stable, inequality increased the consequences of the birth lottery (parental position matters more in dollar terms though relative mobility unchanged)

Result: Large and persistent geographic variation in mobility exists across US regions and commuting zones; some areas show higher mobility (e.g., Mountain) and others lower (e.g., parts of Southeast)

Result: Consolidated mobility series combining age 29–30 income, age 26 income (scaled), and college gradients is virtually flat for cohorts 1971–1993; estimated trend is −0.0006 per year with tight confidence bounds

Conclusion: Rank-based social mobility in the US remained stable from the 1970s through early 1990s cohorts; policy focus should address persistent low-mobility areas and mitigating increased dollar consequences of birth
